title: 108_s1932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Artists' Rights and Theft Prevention Act of 2004" or the "ART Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that intellectual property is crucial for innovation and economic development, with industries like music, film, and software contributing significantly to the US economy. The Act aims to address illegal reproduction and distribution facilitated by the Internet and technology. The No Electronic Theft (NET) Act, passed in 1997, strengthens copyright and trademark laws to prosecute individuals involved in large-scale illegal reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works. The Act addresses the economic harm caused by copyright infringements, particularly focusing on the distribution of prerelease commercial works and the threat posed by camcorders in movie theaters. Online theft of intellectual property, particularly through camcorders, poses a serious threat to the motion picture industry and the overall economy. Federal legislation is needed to combat this issue due to its significant negative impact on the United States economy. The importance of protecting intellectual property rights, especially in industries like music, film, and software, is crucial for the US economy. Theft and unauthorized distribution of intellectual property are common occurrences across state and international borders. Criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater are outlined in Section 3. Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code, outlines criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater. Offenders face imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both for a first offense, and up to 6 years for subsequent offenses. Additionally, the court may order the forfeiture and destruction of unauthorized copies of protected works. Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code, criminalizes unauthorized recording of motion pictures in theaters. The law allows for detention of suspects for questioning and provides immunity to theater owners, employees, and licensors. Authorized activities by law enforcement are not restricted under this section. During the preparation of the presentence report, victims of an offense under this section can submit a victim impact statement to the probation officer. The statement should identify the victim, the extent of injury and loss, and the estimated economic impact of the offense. It should also include producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate works affected by the offense. Legal representatives of these individuals are also included in the statement. The terms related to copyright and audiovisual works are defined in Title 17. An audiovisual recording device is described as any technology capable of recording or transmitting copyrighted motion pictures. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in Title 18. SEC. 4. Criminal infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution includes unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a motion picture exhibition facility. The term 'motion picture exhibition facility' is defined as a venue primarily used for showing copyrighted movies to the public or an assembled group outside of a family circle. Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to criminalize willful copyright infringement for commercial gain or distribution of copyrighted works exceeding $1,000 in value. This includes making works available on public computer networks intended for commercial distribution. The definition of 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' includes computer programs, musical works, motion pictures, sound recordings, and motion pictures available in theaters but not yet for sale to the public. This definition clarifies what constitutes unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works. The amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code, increases criminal penalties for offenses related to unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works, including imprisonment for up to 3 years and fines. The amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code, increases criminal penalties for unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Civil remedies for infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution are addressed in Section 5. Preregistration procedures for works being prepared for commercial distribution are established under Section 408 of title 17, United States Code. The Register of Copyrights will issue regulations within 180 days for preregistration of works with a history of infringement before authorized distribution. Applicants must submit an application, deposit, and fee within 3 months of the work's first publication. The text discusses the consequences of untimely application for infringement actions under copyright law. It states that an action for infringement shall be dismissed if certain items are not submitted to the Copyright Office within a specified timeframe. Additionally, amendments are made to sections 411(a) and 412 of title 17, United States Code, regarding infringement actions and exclusions for preregistered works. SEC. 6. FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes within 180 days of this Act. They are authorized to make amendments following specific procedures and must ensure guidelines are appropriate. The Federal sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes will be reviewed and potentially amended within 180 days of this Act. The review will focus on determining sentencing enhancements for offenses involving unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works and assessing the adequacy of guidelines in addressing losses from unauthorized distribution over the Internet. The Federal sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes will be reviewed within 180 days of this Act to determine sentencing enhancements for unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works and assess losses from unauthorized distribution over the Internet. It is important to adequately reflect harm to victims from copyright infringement when authorities cannot determine the extent of reproduction or distribution. Authorization of appropriations of $5,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2009 to prosecute violations of intellectual property rights under specified sections of the United States Code.
